{{About|the organization|their published licenses|Creative Commons license|usage of product|List of major Creative Commons licensed works}} {{Infobox organization | name = Creative Commons | logo = [[File:CC-logo.svg|Creative Commons logo|200px]] | founded_date = {{start date and age|2001|1|15}}<ref>{{cite web|url=http://whois.domaintools.com/creativecommons.org|title=CreativeCommons.org WHOIS, DNS, & Domain Info – DomainTools|work=[[WHOIS]]|date=|accessdate=2016-07-11}}</ref> | founder = [[Lawrence Lessig]] | key_people = [[Ryan Merkley]] (CEO) | type = [[501(c)(3)]] | tax_id = 04-3585301 | focus = Expansion of "reasonable", flexible copyright | method = [[Creative Commons license]] | homepage = {{ConditionalURL}} }}
'''Creative Commons''' ('''CC''') is an American [[non-profit organization]] devoted to expanding the range of [[creativity|creative]] works available for others to build upon legally and to share.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://creativecommons.org/faq/|title=Frequently Asked Questions|publisher=Creative Commons |date=4 August 2016|accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref> The organization has released several [[copyright]]-[[license]]s known as [[Creative Commons license]]s free of charge to the public. These licenses allow creators to communicate which rights they reserve, and which rights they [[waive]] for the benefit of recipients or other creators. An easy-to-understand one-page explanation of rights, with associated visual symbols, explains the specifics of each Creative Commons license. Creative Commons licenses do not replace copyright, but are based upon it. They replace individual negotiations for specific rights between copyright owner (licensor) and [[licensee]], which are necessary under an "all rights reserved" copyright management, with a "some rights reserved" management employing standardized licenses for re-use cases where no commercial compensation is sought by the copyright owner. The result is an agile, low-overhead and low-cost copyright-management regime, benefiting both copyright owners and licensees.
The organization was founded in 2001 by [[Lawrence Lessig]], [[Hal Abelson]], and [[Eric Eldred]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://creativecommons.org/about/history|title=Creative Commons: History|accessdate=2011-10-09}}</ref> with the support of [[Center for the Public Domain]]. The first article in a general interest publication about Creative Commons, written by [[Hal Plotkin]], was published in February 2002.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?f=/g/a/2002/02/11/creatcom.DTL|title=All Hail Creative Commons / Stanford professor and author Lawrence Lessig plans a legal insurrection|last=Plotkin|first=Hal|work=|publisher=SFGate.com|accessdate=2011-03-08|date=11 February 2002}}</ref> The first set of copyright licenses was released in December 2002.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://creativecommons.org/about/history/|title=History of Creative Commons|accessdate=2009-11-08}}</ref> The founding management team that developed the licenses and built the Creative Commons infrastructure as we know it today included [[Molly Shaffer Van Houweling]], Glenn Otis Brown, Neeru Paharia, and Ben Adida.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://creativecommons.org/press-releases/entry/3483|title=Creative Commons Announces New Management Team|last=Haughey|first=Matt|date=2002-09-18|publisher=creativecommons.org|accessdate=2013-05-07}}</ref>
In 2002 the [[Open Content Project]], a 1998 precursor project by [[David A. Wiley]], announced the Creative Commons as successor project and Wiley joined as CC director.<ref>{{cite web|archivedate=2003-08-02|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20030802222546/http://opencontent.org/|url=http://opencontent.org/|title=OpenContent is officially closed. And that's just fine.|publisher=opencontent.org|date=30 June 2003|accessdate=2016-02-21|quote=I'm closing OpenContent because I think Creative Commons is doing a better job of providing licensing options which will stand up in court|authorlink=David A. Wiley|author=Wiley, David A.}}</ref><ref>[https://blog.creativecommons.org/2003/06/23/creativecommonswelcomesdavidwileyaseducationaluselicenseprojectlead/ Creative Commons Welcomes David Wiley as Educational Use License Project Lead] by matt on creativecommons.org (June 23rd, 2003)</ref> [[Aaron Swartz]] played a role in the early stages of Creative Commons,<ref>{{cite web|url=https://creativecommons.org/weblog/entry/36298|title=Remembering Aaron Swartz |last=Lessig|first=Lawrence |date=2013-01-12 |publisher=creativecommons.org |accessdate=2013-05-07}}</ref> as did [[Matthew Haughey]].<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://creativecommons.org/2005/04/04/matthaughey/|title=Matt Haughey - Creative Commons|date=2005-04-04|work=Creative Commons|access-date=2018-01-11|language=en-US}}</ref>
As of May 2018 there were an estimated 1.4 billion works licensed under the various Creative Commons licenses.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stateof.creativecommons.org/|title=State of the Commons – Creative Commons 2017|last=|first=|date=|website=stateof.creativecommons.org|language=en-US|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018-01-13}}</ref> [[Wikipedia]] uses one of these licenses.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://wikimediafoundation.org/wiki/Terms_of_Use |title=Wikimedia Foundation Terms of Use |accessdate=June 11, 2012}}</ref> As of May 2018, [[Flickr]] alone hosts over 415 million Creative Commons licensed photos.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.flickr.com/creativecommons/|title=Flickr: Creative Commons|website=www.flickr.com|language=en-us|access-date=2018-01-16}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://stateof.creativecommons.org|title=State of the Commons 2017|website=State of the Commons 2017|language=en-US|access-date=2018-05-09}}</ref>
Creative Commons is governed by a board of directors. Their licenses have been embraced by many as a way for creators to take control of how they choose to share their copyrighted works.
==Purpose and goal== [[File:GoldenNica CreativeCommons.jpg|thumb|[[Prix Ars Electronica|Golden Nica Award]] (2004)]] [[File:Lawrence Lessig (9).jpg|thumb|[[Lawrence Lessig]] (January 2008)]] [[File:Creative Commons Japan Seminar-200709-1.jpg|thumb|Creative Commons Japan Seminar, [[Tokyo]] (2007)]] [[File:CC some rights reserved.svg|thumb|CC some rights reserved]] [[File:Creativecommons spanien.jpg|thumb|A sign in a pub in [[Granada]] notifies customers that the music they are listening to is freely distributable under a Creative Commons license.]] [[File:Made-with-cc.pdf|thumb|''Made with Creative Commons'', a 2017 book describing the value of CC licenses.]] Creative Commons has been described as being at the forefront of the [[copyleft]] movement, which seeks to support the building of a richer [[public domain]] by providing an alternative to the automatic "all rights reserved" [[copyright]], and has been dubbed "some rights reserved".<ref>{{cite news| first= Sharee L. | last= Broussard| title= The copyleft movement: creative commons licensing | publisher= Communication Research Trends | url=http://cscc.scu.edu/trends/v26/v26_n3.pdf | date=September 2007 | accessdate=2015-10-20}}</ref> David Berry and Giles Moss have credited Creative Commons with generating interest in the issue of [[intellectual property]] and contributing to the re-thinking of the role of the "[[commons]]" in the "[[information age]]". Beyond that, Creative Commons has provided "institutional, practical and legal support for individuals and groups wishing to experiment and communicate with culture more freely."<ref>{{cite web|last=Berry |first=David |url=http://www.freesoftwaremagazine.com/articles/commons_without_commonality/ |title=On the "Creative Commons": a critique of the commons without commonalty |publisher=Free Software Magazine |date=15 July 2005 |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref>
Creative Commons attempts to counter what [[Lawrence Lessig]], founder of Creative Commons, considers to be a dominant and increasingly restrictive [[permission culture]]. Lessig describes this as "a culture in which creators get to create only with the permission of the powerful, or of creators from the past."<ref>{{Cite book| first=Lawrence | last=Lessig |url=http://www.free-culture.cc/freeculture.pdf |year=2004 | title=Free Culture | publisher=Penguin Press | location=New York | page=8 |format=PDF| isbn=978-1-59420-006-9| accessdate=2015-10-20}}</ref> Lessig maintains that modern culture is dominated by traditional content distributors in order to maintain and strengthen their monopolies on cultural products such as popular music and popular cinema, and that Creative Commons can provide alternatives to these restrictions.<ref>{{Cite news| author=Ermert, Monika | title=Germany debuts Creative Commons | work=The Register | date=2004-06-15| url=https://www.theregister.co.uk/2004/06/15/german_creative_commons/ }}</ref><ref>{{cite web| author=Lessig, Lawrence| year=2006| title=Lawrence Lessig on Creative Commons and the Remix Culture | format=mp3 | work=Talking with Talis | url=http://talk.talis.com/archives/2006/01/lawrence_lessig.html |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080205034639/http://talk.talis.com/archives/2006/01/lawrence_lessig.html | archivedate=2008-02-05 | accessdate=2006-04-07}}</ref>
==Creative Commons Network== Until April 2018 Creative Commons had over 100 affiliates working in over 75 jurisdictions to support and promote CC activities around the world.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://wiki.creativecommons.org/CC_Affiliate_Network |title=CC Affiliate Network |publisher=Creative Commons |accessdate= 15 March 2015}}</ref> In 2018 this affiliate network has been restructured into a network organisation.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://creativecommons.org/about/global-affiliate-network/network-strategy/|title=Network Strategy - Creative Commons|publisher=}}</ref> The network no longer relies on affiliate organisation but on individual membership organised in Chapter.
===South Korea=== '''Creative Commons Korea''' ('''CC Korea''') is the affiliated network of Creative Commons in South Korea. In March 2005, CC Korea was initiated by Jongsoo Yoon (in Korean: 윤종수), a Presiding Judge of Incheon District Court, as a project of Korea Association for Infomedia Law (KAFIL). The major Korean portal sites, including Daum and Naver, have been participating in the use of Creative Commons licences. In January 2009, the Creative Commons Korea Association was consequently founded as a non-profit incorporated association. Since then, CC Korea has been actively promoting the liberal and open culture of creation as well as leading the diffusion of Creative Common in the country.
*Creative Commons Korea<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cckorea.org/xe/?mid=main |title=Creative Commons Korea |publisher=CCkorea.org |date= |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref> *Creative Commons Asia Conference 2010<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.creativecommons.org/CC_Asia_Conference_2010 |title=CC Asia Conference 2010 |publisher=Creative Commons |date=21 July 2010 |accessdate=20 December 2011}}</ref>
===Bassel Khartabil=== [[Bassel Khartabil]] was a Palestinian Syrian open source software developer and has served as project lead and public affiliate for Creative Commons Syria.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://wiki.creativecommons.org/Syria|title=Syria|publisher=creativecommons.org}}</ref> From March 15, 2012 he was detained by the Syrian government in Damascus at Adra Prison. On October 17, 2015 Creative Commons Board of Directors approved a resolution calling for Bassel Khartabil's release.<ref>[https://creativecommons.org/weblog/entry/46253 Board of Directors approves resolution calling for Bassel Khartabil release – Creative Commons Blog]. Creative Commons (2015-10-17). Retrieved on 2016-11-02.</ref> In 2017 Bassel's wife received confirmation that Bassel had been executed shortly after she lost contact with him in 2015.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/middle-east/bassel-khartabil-safadi-executed-syria-activist-dead-prison-widow-confirms-democracy-adra-damascus-a7872771.html |title=Bassel Khartabil Safadi dead: One of Syria's most famous activists has been executed in prison, widow confirms |first=Bethan |last=McKernan |date=2 August 2017 |publisher=''The Independent''}}</ref>
==Criticism== All current CC licenses (except the CC0 Public Domain Dedication tool) require attribution, which can be inconvenient for works based on multiple other works.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://blog.ninapaley.com/2010/03/04/the-limits-of-attribution/ |title = The Limits of Attribution |last1 = Paley |first1 = Nina |authorlink1 = Nina Paley |date = 2010-03-04 |work = Nina Paley's Blog |accessdate = 2013-01-30 }}</ref> Critics feared that Creative Commons could erode the copyright system over time<ref name="John Dvorak, Creative Commons Humbug">{{Cite journal |url=https://www.pcmag.com/article2/0,2817,1838244,00.asp |title=Creative Commons Humbug |author=Dvorak, John |publisher=PC Magazine |date=July 2005 }}</ref> or allow "some of our most precious resources – the creativity of individuals – to be simply tossed into the commons to be exploited by whomever has spare time and a magic marker."<ref name="Maritza Schaeffer, Note and Comment: Contemporary Issues In the Visual Art World: How Useful Are Creative Commons Licenses?">{{cite news | first= Maritza | last= Schaeffer | title= Note and Comment: Contemporary Issues in the Visual Art Realm: How Useful are Creative Commons Licenses? | publisher= Journal of Law and Policy | url= http://practicum.brooklaw.edu/sites/default/files/print/pdfs/journals/journal-law-and-policy/volume-17/issue-1/jlp_v17i_7.pdf | archive-url= https://web.archive.org/web/20160204120332/http://practicum.brooklaw.edu/sites/default/files/print/pdfs/journals/journal-law-and-policy/volume-17/issue-1/jlp_v17i_7.pdf | dead-url= yes | archive-date= 2016-02-04 | year= 2009 | accessdate= 2015-10-20 }}</ref>
Critics also worried that the lack of rewards for content producers will dissuade artists from publishing their work, and questioned whether Creative Commons is the [[commons]] that it purports to be.<ref name="Niva Elkin-Koren, Exploring Creative Commons: A Skeptical View of a Worthy Pursuit">{{cite web| first= Niva| last= Elkin-Koren| title= Exploring Creative Commons: A Skeptical View of a Worthy Pursuit | publisher= The Future of the Public Domain (P. Bernt Hugenholtz and Lucie Guibault, eds.)| ssrn=885466 | year=2006 }}</ref>
Creative Commons founder Lawrence Lessig countered that copyright laws have not always offered the strong and seemingly indefinite protection that today's law provides. Rather, the duration of copyright used to be limited to much shorter terms of years, and some works never gained protection because they did not follow the now-abandoned compulsory format.<ref name="Lawrence Lessig, The Creative Commons">{{cite web| first= Lawrence| last= Lessig| title= The Creative Commons | publisher= 65 Mont. L. Rev. 1| url= | year=2004}}</ref>
The maintainers of [[Debian]], a [[GNU]] and [[Linux distribution]] known for its rigid adherence to a particular definition of [[software freedom]],<ref name="debian-social-contract">{{cite web |url=http://www.debian.org/social_contract |title=Debian Social Contract |publisher=Debian |date=2004-04-26 |accessdate=2013-11-26 }}</ref> rejected the Creative Commons Attribution License prior to version 3 as incompatible with the [[Debian Free Software Guidelines]] (DFSG) due to the license's anti-[[Digital rights management|DRM]] provisions (which might, due to ambiguity, be covering more than DRM) and its requirement that downstream users remove an author's credit upon request from the author.<ref name="debian-cc20-summary">{{cite web |url=http://evan.prodromou.name/ccsummary/ccsummary.html |title=Summary of Creative Commons 2.0 Licenses |publisher=debian-legal (mailing list) |author=Prodromou, Evan |date=3 April 2005 |deadurl=bot: unknown |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20060519162310/http://evan.prodromou.name/ccsummary/ccsummary.html |archivedate=19 May 2006 |df= }}</ref> Version 3.0 of the Creative Commons licenses addressed these concerns<ref>{{cite web |url = https://creativecommons.org/weblog/entry/7249 |title = Version 3.0 Launched |accessdate = 2007-07-05 |publisher = Creative Commons |date = 2007-02-23 |first = Mia |last = Garlick}}</ref> and except for the non commercial variants are considered to be compatible with the DFSG.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://wiki.debian.org/DFSGLicenses#CreativeCommonsShare-Alike.28CC-SA.29v3.0 |title = The DFSG and Software Licenses – Creative Commons Share-Alike (CC-SA) v3.0 |accessdate = 2009-03-16 |publisher = Debian Wiki }}</ref>
Kent Anderson, writing for ''The Scholarly Kitchen'', a blog of the [[Society for Scholarly Publishing]], criticizes CC as being dependent on copyright and not really departing from it, and as being more complex and complicating than the latter – thus the public does not scrutinize CC, reflexively accepting it as one would a [[EULA|software license]] – while at the same time weakening the rights provided by copyright. Anderson ends up concluding that this is the point, and that "Creative Commons receives significant funding from large information companies like [[Google]], [[Nature Publishing Group]], and [[RedHat]]", and that Google money is especially linked to CC's history; for him, CC is "an organization designed to promulgate the interests of technology companies and Silicon Valley generally".<ref>{{cite web |url=https://scholarlykitchen.sspnet.org/2014/04/02/does-creative-commons-make-sense/ |title=Does Creative Commons Make Sense? |last=Anderson |first=Kent |date=April 2, 2014 |website=The Scholarly Kitchen |publisher=[[Society for Scholarly Publishing]] |access-date=December 21, 2017}}</ref>
===License proliferation and incompatibility=== [[Mako Hill]] asserted that Creative Commons fails to establish a "base level of freedom" that all Creative Commons licenses must meet, and with which all licensors and users must comply. "By failing to take any firm ethical position and draw any line in the sand, CC is a missed opportunity. ... CC has replaced what could have been a call for a world where 'essential rights are unreservable' with the relatively hollow call for 'some rights reserved.{{' "}} He also argued that Creative Commons worsens [[license proliferation]], by providing multiple licenses that are [[license compatibility|incompatible]].<ref name="Mako Hill, Towards a Standard of Freedom">{{cite web |url=http://mako.cc/writing/toward_a_standard_of_freedom.html |title=Towards a Standard of Freedom: Creative Commons and the Free Software Movement |author=Hill, Benjamin Mako |date=29 July 2005 }}</ref>
The Creative Commons website states, "Since each of the six CC licenses functions differently, resources placed under different licenses may not necessarily be combined with one another without violating the license terms."<ref>{{Cite journal |url = http://learn.creativecommons.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/10/cclearn-explanations-cc-license-compatability.pdf |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20091025045901/http://learn.creativecommons.org/wp-content/uploads/2009/10/cclearn-explanations-cc-license-compatability.pdf |dead-url = yes |archive-date = 25 October 2009 |title = CC Learn Explanations: Remixing OER: A guide to License Compatibility |publisher = Creative Commons CC Learn |accessdate = 29 November 2010 }}</ref> Works licensed under incompatible licenses may not be recombined in a [[derivative work]] without obtaining permission from the copyright owner.<ref>{{cite web |url = http://wiki.creativecommons.org/FAQ#Can_I_combine_two_different_Creative_Commons_licensed_works.3F_Can_I_combine_a_Creative_Commons_licensed_work_with_another_non-CC_licensed_work.3F |title = Can I combine two different Creative Commons licensed works? Can I combine a Creative Commons licensed work with another non-CC licensed work? |work = FAQ |publisher = Creative Commons |accessdate = 16 September 2009 }}</ref><ref name="Creative Commons Attribution ShareAlike 3.0 Unported">{{cite web |url =https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-sa/3.0/ |title = Creative Commons Attribution ShareAlike 3.0 Unported |publisher = Creative Commons |accessdate = 18 November 2009 }}</ref><ref name="Creative Commons Attribution Non-Commercial Share-Alike 3.0 Unported">{{cite web |url =https://creativecommons.org/licenses/by-nc-sa/3.0/ |title = Creative Commons Attribution Share-Alike 3.0 Unported |publisher = Creative Commons |accessdate = 18 November 2009 }}</ref>
[[Richard Stallman]] of the [[Free Software Foundation|FSF]] stated in 2005 that he couldn't support Creative Commons as an activity because "it adopted some additional licenses which do not give everyone that minimum freedom", that freedom being "the freedom to share, noncommercially, any published work".<ref>{{cite web |url = http://www.fsf.org/blogs/rms/entry-20050920.html |first = Richard M. |last = Stallman |title = Fireworks in Montreal |publisher = FSF Blogs |accessdate = 18 November 2009 }}</ref> Those licenses have since been retired by Creative Commons.<ref>{{cite web |url = https://creativecommons.org/licenses/nc/1.0/ |title = NonCommercial 1.0 Generic (CC NC 1.0) |publisher = Creative Commons |accessdate = 13 November 2015 }}</ref>
===License misuse=== [[File:CC guidant les contributeurs.jpg|thumb|right|''Creative Commons guiding the contributors''. This image is a derivative work of ''[[Liberty Leading the People]]'' by [[Eugène Delacroix]].]]
Creative Commons is only a service provider for standardized license text, not a party in any agreement. Abusive users can brand the copyrighted works of legitimate copyright holders with Creative Commons licenses and re-upload these works to the internet.{{who|date=November 2018}} No central database of Creative Commons works is controlling all licensed works and the responsibility of the Creative Commons system rests entirely with those using the licences.<ref name="Andrew Orlowski, Tragedy of the Creative Commons" >{{cite web| first= Andrew | last= Orlowski| title= The Tragedy of the Creative Commons| publisher= | url=http://andreworlowski.com/2009/07/16/the-tragedy-of-the-creative-commons/ |date=July 2009}}</ref> This situation is, however, not specific to Creative Commons. All copyright owners must individually defend their rights and no central database of copyrighted works or existing license agreements exists. The [[United States Copyright Office]] does keep a database of all works registered with it, but absence of registration does not imply absence of copyright.
Although Creative Commons offers multiple licenses for different uses, some critics suggested that the licenses still do not address the differences among the media or among the various concerns that different authors have.<ref name="Niva Elkin-Koren, Exploring Creative Commons: A Skeptical View of a Worthy Pursuit" />
Lessig wrote that the point of Creative Commons is to provide a middle ground between two extreme views of copyright protection – one demanding that all rights be controlled, and the other arguing that none should be controlled. Creative Commons provides a third option that allows authors to pick and choose which rights they want to control and which they want to grant to others. The multitude of licenses reflects the multitude of rights that can be passed on to subsequent creators.<ref name="Lawrence Lessig, The Creative Commons" />
===Criticism of the non-commercial license=== [[Erik Möller]] raised concerns about the use of Creative Commons' non-commercial license. Works distributed under the Creative Commons Non-Commercial license are not compatible with many open-content sites, including Wikipedia, which explicitly allow and encourage some commercial uses. Möller explained that "the people who are likely to be hurt by an -NC license are not large corporations, but small publications like weblogs, advertising-funded radio stations, or local newspapers."<ref name="Erik Moller, The Case for Free Use: Reasons Not to Use a Creative Commons -NC License">{{cite web |url=http://www.opensourcejahrbuch.de/download/jb2006/chapter_06/osjb2006-06-02-en-moeller.pdf |title=The Case for Free Use: Reasons Not to Use a Creative Commons -NC License |author=Moeller, Erik |publisher=Open Source Jahrbuch |year=2006 }}</ref>
Lessig responded that the current copyright regime also harms compatibility and that authors can lessen this incompatibility by choosing the least restrictive license.<ref name="Lawrence Lessig, CC in Review: Lawrence Lessig on Important Freedoms">{{cite web| first= Lawrence| last= Lessig| authorlink=Lawrence Lessig| title= CC in Review: Lawrence Lessig on Important Freedoms | publisher= Creative Commons| url=https://creativecommons.org/weblog/entry/5719 | year=2005 | accessdate=2015-10-20}}</ref> Additionally, the non-commercial license is useful for preventing someone else from capitalizing on an author's work when the author still plans to do so in the future.<ref name="Lawrence Lessig, CC in Review: Lawrence Lessig on Important Freedoms" /><ref>{{cite web|url=https://sites.google.com/site/hmdmhdfmhdjmzdtjmzdtzktdkztdjz/commons|title=On Free, and the Differences between Culture and Code|publisher=[[Chaos Communication Congress|23C3 ''Who can you trust?'']]|year=2006|type=video|id=google video docid=7661663613180520595|accessdate=2014-02-07}}</ref> The non-commercial licenses have also been criticized for being too vague about which uses count as "commercial" and "non-commercial".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.cnet.com/news/does-the-noncommercial-creative-commons-license-make-sense/ |title=Does the Noncommercial Creative Commons license make sense? |date=2007-11-26|author=Haff, Gordon |publisher=[[CNET]]|accessdate=2015-02-22}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://lists.ibiblio.org/pipermail/cc-licenses/2005-April/002215.html |title=Use cases for NonCommercial license clause |date=2005-04-19|author=Prodromou, Evan |authorlink=Evan Prodromou|publisher=cc-licenses mailing list|accessdate=2015-02-22}}</ref>
Great Minds, a non-profit educational publisher that released works under an -NC license, sued [[FedEx]] for violating the license because a school had used its services to mass-produce photocopies of the work, thus commercially exploiting the works. A U.S. judge dismissed the case in February 2017, ruling that FedEx was an intermediary, and that the provision of the license "does not limit a licensee's ability to use third parties in exercising the rights granted [by the licensor]."<ref name="ars-greatminds">{{cite web|title=Odd lawsuit fails to ding FedEx for allowing copies of CC-licensed material|url=https://arstechnica.com/tech-policy/2017/02/odd-lawsuit-fails-to-ding-fedex-for-allowing-copies-of-cc-licensed-material/|website=Ars Technica|accessdate=27 February 2017|date=2017-02-27}}</ref> Great Minds appealed the decision to the [[United States Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit]] later that year.<ref>{{cite news |first=Sean |last=Cavanagh |date=July 20, 2017 |title=Open Ed. Provider Appealing Decision in Closely Watched Lawsuit |url=https://marketbrief.edweek.org/marketplace-k-12/open-ed-provider-appealing-decision-in-closely-watched-lawsuit/ |website=EdWeek Market Brief |publisher=Editorial Projects in Education, Inc |accessdate=March 23, 2018 }}</ref> The 2nd Circuit upheld the lower court's decision in March 2018,<ref>{{cite news |first=RJ |last=Vogt |date=March 21, 2018 |title=2nd Circ. Upholds FedEx Win In Textbook Copying Suit |url=https://www.law360.com/articles/1024593/2nd-circ-upholds-fedex-win-in-textbook-copying-suit |website=Law360 |accessdate=March 23, 2018 }}</ref> concluding that FedEx neither infringed copyrights nor violated the license. One of circuit judges [[Susan L. Carney]] argued in the court statement:
<blockquote>We hold that, in view of the absence of any clear license language to the contrary, licensees may use third‐party agents such as commercial reproduction services in furtherance of their own permitted noncommercial uses. Because FedEx acted as the mere agent of licensee school districts when it reproduced Great Minds' materials, and because there is no dispute that the school districts themselves sought to use Great Minds' materials for permissible purposes, we conclude that FedEx's activities did not breach the license or violate Great Minds' copyright.<ref>{{cite news |first=Adam |last=Klasfeld |date=March 21, 2018 |url=https://www.courthousenews.com/second-circuit-clears-fedex-in-education-copyright-case/ |title=Second Circuit Clears FedEx in Education Copyright Case |website=Courthouse News Service |accessdate=March 23, 2018 }}</ref><ref>{{cite court |litigants=Great Minds v. FedEx Office and Print Services, Inc. |court=2d Cir. |date=March 21, 2018 |url=https://www.courthousenews.com/wp-content/uploads/2018/03/fedex-copyright.pdf |accessdate=March 23, 2018 |via=Courthouse News Service }}</ref></blockquote>
===Personality rights=== In 2007, [[Virgin Mobile Australia]] launched a bus stop advertising campaign which promoted its mobile phone text messaging service using the work of amateur photographers who uploaded their work to the photo-sharing site [[Flickr]] using a [[Creative Commons Attribution 2.5|Creative Commons by Attribution]] license. Users licensing their images this way freed their work for use by any other entity, as long as the original creator was attributed credit, without any other compensation being required. Virgin upheld this single restriction by printing a URL, leading to the photographer's Flickr page, on each of their ads. However, one picture depicted 15-year-old Alison Chang posing for a photo at her church's fund-raising carwash, with the superimposed, mocking slogan "Dump Your Pen Friend".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.out-law.com/page-8494 |title=Lawsuit over Virgin Mobile's use of Flickr girl blames Creative Commons |work=Out-law.com |date=2007-09-25 |accessdate=2013-05-23}}</ref><ref name="permission">{{cite news|first=Noam|last=Cohen|title=Use My Photo? Not Without Permission|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2007/10/01/technology/01link.html|quote=One moment, Alison Chang, a 15-year-old student from Dallas, is cheerfully goofing around at a local church-sponsored car wash, posing with a friend for a photo. Weeks later, that photo is posted online and catches the eye of an ad agency in Australia, and the altered image of Alison appears on a billboard in Adelaide as part of a [[Virgin Mobile]] advertising campaign.|work=[[The New York Times]]|date=2007-10-01|accessdate=2013-07-24}}</ref> Chang sued Virgin Mobile and Creative Commons. The photo was taken by Chang's church youth counsellor, Justin Ho-Wee Wong, who uploaded the image to Flickr under the Creative Commons license.<ref name="permission"/>
{{quote|The case hinges on privacy, the right of people not to have their likeness used in an ad without permission. So, while Mr. Wong may have given away his rights as a photographer, he did not, and could not, give away Alison's [[Personality rights|rights]]. In the lawsuit, which Mr. Wong is also a party to, there is an argument that Virgin did not honor all the terms of the nonrestrictive license.<ref name="permission"/>}}
On 27 November 2007, Chang filed for a voluntary dismissal of the lawsuit against Creative Commons, focusing their lawsuit against Virgin Mobile.<ref>{{cite news|last=Gross|first=Grant|title=Lawsuit Against Creative Commons Dropped|work=[[PC World]]|date=2007-12-01|url=https://www.pcworld.com/article/140189/lawsuit_against_creative_commons_dropped.html|accessdate=2008-05-25}}</ref> The case was thrown out of court due to lack of jurisdiction and subsequently Virgin Mobile did not incur any damages towards the plaintiff.<ref>{{cite news|last=LaVine|first=Lindsay|title=Use Photos in Advertisements? Take These Steps to Avoid a Lawsuit|url=http://www.nbcnews.com/id/50261013/ns/business-small_business/t/use-photos-advertisements-take-these-steps-avoid-lawsuit/|accessdate=2013-07-24|newspaper=[[NBC News]]|date=2012-12-20}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=May 2012}} {{Use British English|date=May 2012}} {{Infobox person | name = Cynthia Payne | birth_date = {{birth date|1932|12|24|df=yes}} | birth_place = [[Bognor Regis]], [[Sussex]], England, UK | death_date = {{death date and age|2015|11|15|1932|12|24|df=yes}} | death_place = England, UK | nationality = British | notable works = ''Entertaining at Home'' | occupation = [[Procuring (prostitution)|Madam]], [[brothel|brothel keeper]] | website = {{url|http://cynthia-payne.co.uk/}} }} '''Cynthia Payne''' (24 December 1932{{spaced ndash}}15 November 2015) was an English brothel keeper<ref>{{Cite news|title = Brothel keeper Cynthia Payne dies|url = https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/uk-34828890|newspaper = BBC News|accessdate = 2015-11-16|date = 2015-11-15}}</ref> and party hostess who made headlines in the 1970s and 1980s, when she was acquitted of running a [[brothel]] at 32 Ambleside Avenue, in [[Streatham]], a southwestern suburb of [[London]].<ref> {{cite news |url=http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/court_and_social/the_hitch/article873860.ece |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130505072930/http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/life_and_style/court_and_social/the_hitch/article873860.ece |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 May 2013 |title= Cynthia Payne trial |date=12 February 1987 |publisher=[[The Times]] |accessdate=2008-04-04 |last= |first= | location=London}} </ref><ref name="TimesOnThisDay">{{cite news|url=http://www.thetimes.co.uk/tto/life/courtsocial/article1822606.ece|title=On This Day - The Times, February 12, 1987 |date=12 February 2003|work=[[The Times]]|accessdate=20 February 2013}}</ref>
Payne first came to national attention in 1978 when police raided her home and found a sex party was in progress. Men paid with [[luncheon voucher]]s to dress up in lingerie and be spanked by young women.<ref name="Davies">Hugh Davies [https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/uknews/1478955/Paynes-sex-party-souvenirs-for-sale.html "Payne's sex party souvenirs for sale"], ''Daily Telegraph'', 14 December 2004</ref> Police found 53 men at her residence, in varying levels of undress, which included "a [[Peerage|peer of the realm]], an [[Member of Parliament|MP]], a number of solicitors and company directors and several vicars". A cartoon in the press at the time, according to [[Sarah Baxter]] in ''[[The Sunday Times]]'', "showed a vicar in bed with a prostitute, confronted by a policeman. 'I demand to see my solicitor,' said the vicar, 'who is in the next bedroom.'"<ref >{{cite news|last=Baxter|first=Sarah|url=http://www.thesundaytimes.co.uk/sto/comment/columns/SarahBaxter/article1636348.ece|title=So long, Madam Cyn, a spanking, ethical example to us all|work=The Sunday Times|location=London|date=22 November 2015|accessdate=22 November 2015}} {{subscription required}}</ref>
When the case came to trial in 1980, Payne was sentenced to eighteen months in prison, reduced to a fine and six months on appeal.<ref name="BBC1">[http://news.bbc.co.uk/onthisday/hi/dates/stories/february/11/newsid_2539000/2539565.stm "1987: Mrs Payne is no brothel Madam"], BBC On This Day, 11 February</ref> She served four months in [[Holloway prison]].<ref name="Davies"/>
In 1986, the police raided Payne’s home again, this time during a "special party" she was hosting after shooting of the film of her life had been completed. Although she was acquitted on this occasion,<ref name="BBC1"/> the resulting court case in 1987 made headlines for several weeks with lurid tales, some details of which she aired on ''[[The Dame Edna Experience]]'' in 1987, with co-guests Sir [[John Mills]] and [[Rudolf Nureyev]], on which she also launched her book, ''Entertaining at Home''. The court case ended Payne’s career as a party giver.
On the programme, Payne expressed an interest in becoming a [[Member of Parliament]] in order to change Britain's sex laws, which she followed through by standing for Parliament as a candidate for the Payne and Pleasure Party in the [[Kensington by-election, 1988|Kensington by-election in July 1988]], followed by her standing in her own area of [[Streatham (UK Parliament constituency)|Streatham]] for the [[Rainbow Dream Ticket]] in the [[United Kingdom general election, 1992|1992 UK General Election]]. She did not gain a parliamentary seat.
There are two films that are loosely based on her life, both released in 1987: ''[[Wish You Were Here (1987 movie)|Wish You Were Here]]'', about her adolescence, with [[Emily Lloyd]] in the lead role, and ''[[Personal Services]]'', about her adult life, starring [[Julie Walters]]. Both were written (and ''Wish You Were Here'' was directed) by [[David Leland]].
Payne made appearances as an [[public speaking|after-dinner speaker]] and launched a range of "adult" services and products in 2006.
Payne died on 15 November 2015, aged 82.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://news.sky.com/story/notorious-brothel-owner-cynthia-payne-dies-10339425 |title=Notorious Brothel Owner Cynthia Payne Dies |publisher=[[Sky News]] |work=news.sky.com |date=15 November 2015 |accessdate=15 November 2015 }}</ref> Her family celebrated her life a month later with a colourful [[secular humanist|humanist]] funeral, in accordance with her wishes.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://home.bt.com/news/uk-news/monty-pythons-terry-jones-leads-tributes-at-funeral-of-cynthia-payne-11364027966802|title=Monty Python's Terry Jones leads tributes at funeral of Cynthia Payne|date=9 December 2015|accessdate=10 December 2015|work=BT.com}}</ref>

{{Use dmy dates|date=July 2013}} {{Infobox Government agency |agency_name = [[Kingdom of Thailand]]
Election Commission | type = [[Constitutional organizations of Thailand|Constitutional organization]] |nativename = |nativename_a = คณะกรรมการการเลือกตั้ง |nativename_r = กกต. |logo = File:นายกรัฐมนตรี เดินทางพบ กกต. ณ ศูนย์ราชการ แจ้งวัฒนะ ว - Flickr - Abhisit Vejjajiva (3).jpg |logo_width = 200px |logo_caption = Seal of the Election Commission |seal = |seal_width = |seal_caption = |formed = 9 June 1998 |date1 = |date2 = |date2_name = |preceding1 = |preceding2 = |dissolved = |superseding = |jurisdiction = Kingdom of Thailand |headquarters = No. 120, Ratthaprasatphakdi Building, [[Chaeng Watthana Government Complex]], Chaeng Watthana Rd., Thung Song Hong Subdistrict, [[Lak Si District|Lak Si]], [[Bangkok]], 10210 |employees = |budget = 8,247 million baht (FY2019) |chief1_name = Supachai Somcharoen |chief1_position = '''Chairman''' |chief2_name = Puchong Nutrawong |chief2_position = '''Secretary-General''' |website = [http://www.ect.go.th/ Ect.go.th] |footnotes = }} {{Politics of Thailand}} The '''Election Commission''' ({{lang-th|คณะกรรมการการเลือกตั้ง}}, {{RTGS|''Khana Kammakan Kan Lueaktang''}}) is an [[Independent Government Agencies of Thailand|independent government agency]] and the sole [[election management body]] of [[Thailand]]. It oversees government elections (parliamentary elections and local elections) as well as [[referendum]]s throughout the [[Thailand|Kingdom of Thailand]]. Established by the [[2007 Constitution of Thailand|2007 Constitution]], the Election Commission (EC) has extensive powers to manage, oversee, and regulate the electoral process. The EC has reacted to irregularities in the [[Thai Senate election, 2000|2000 Senate elections]], the [[Thai general election, April 2006|2006 House elections]], and the [[Thai general election, 2007|2007 House elections]], forcing re-elections and disqualifying many candidates. ==Roles and responsibilities== The primary role of the commission is to ensure that [[Elections in Thailand|elections]] carried out in the [[Kingdom of Thailand]] are lawful and compatible with the [[constitution]]. It is also in charge of enforcing national election laws covering: [[House of Representatives of Thailand|House of Representatives]], [[Senate of Thailand|Senate]], [[Administrative divisions of Thailand|Districts]], [[Thai constitutional referendum, 2007|Referendums]], [[Bangkok#Administration|Bangkok gubernatorial]] elections and [[List of political parties in Thailand|political parties]]. Its constitutional duty includes the publication of all election returns, therefore formalizing them. The commissioners also have the right to disqualify a candidate, or call for a re-count for a particular seat. The EC's responsibilities include the organization, management, and counting of all elections and voting in the kingdom. It advises the [[National Assembly of Thailand|National Assembly]] on future policies concerning elections and suffrage. The commission has legal powers as a [[law enforcement agency]] to investigate and indict those who compromise election laws through bribery, corruption, vote buying, or blackmail. The commission has the power to investigate the finances and donor lists of all political parties. It informs the public of elections and their importance. ==Budget== In [[fiscal year|FY2019]] the EC is allocated 8,247 million [[Thai baht|baht]], more than tripling from the FY2018 budget of 2,265 million baht.{{cite book |title=Thailand's Budget in Brief; Fiscal Year 2019 |date=2018 |publisher=Bureau of the Budget |location=Bangkok |page=94 |url=http://www.bb.go.th/en/topic-detail.php?id=8322&mid=456&catID=0 |accessdate=28 September 2018}} ==Structure== The '''Election Commission of Thailand''' is composed of a committee of five members, one [[chairman]] ({{lang-th|ประธานกรรมการการเลือกตั้ง}}) and four election commissioners ({{lang-th|กรรมการการเลือกตั้ง}}). The administrative side of the commission is run by the secretary-general ({{lang-th|เลขาธิการคณะกรรมการการเลือกตั้ง}}). As well as being regular members of the commission, the five members are also given various responsibilities. All commissioners are appointed by the [[King of Thailand|king]], with the advice of the [[Senate of Thailand]]; for a term of seven years. The current commission is the fourth team of election commissioners, appointed 13 December 2013. {{Electioncommssion}} |Chairman of the Election Commission |[[Supachai Somcharoen]] |General Administration |13 December 2013 |- |Election Commissioner |[[Somchai Srisutthiyakorn]] |Election Administration |13 December 2013 |- |Election Commissioner |[[Boonsong Noisophon]] |Investigation and Adjudication |13 December 2013 |- |Election Commissioner |[[Dhirawat Dhirarojvit]] |Political Party Affairs and Referendum |13 December 2013 |- |Election Commissioner |[[Pravich Rattanapian]] |Public Participation |13 December 2013 |- |Secretary-General |[[Puchong Nutrawong]] |Election Commission's Secretariat |13 March 2012 |} ==History== Prior to 1992, the responsibility of overseeing elections fell on the [[Ministry of Interior (Thailand)|Ministry of Interior]] or [[Mahatthai Ministry]]. Under the premiership of [[Anand Panyarachun]] after the [[Thai general election, 1992|Thai general election of 1992]], the prime minister realised the need to create a central and independent body, whose sole purpose was to regulate and manage elections. As a result, on 22 March 1992 the "Committee to Administer and Investigate Elections to the House of Representatives" ({{lang-th|"คณะกรรมการติดตามและสอดส่องดูแลการเลือกตั้งสมาชิกสภาผู้แทนราษฎร"}}) was created, a precursor of the commission. The commission in its current form was created by the [[1997 Constitution of Thailand]]. ===2006 House election=== {{main| Thai general election, April 2006}} The [[Thai general election, April 2006|Thai general election of 2006]], was held on 9 April for the House of Representatives and 19 April for the Senate. The main opposition parties, composed of the [[Democrat Party (Thailand)|Democrat Party]], the [[Chart Thai Party]], and the [[Great People's Party|Mahachon Party]], boycotted the election on the grounds that [[Thaksin Shinawatra]]'s government had unfairly called an election to divert public attention form the [[Shin Corp]] scandal. Despite this, the election went ahead. On 3 April 2006, the [[People's Alliance for Democracy]] (PAD) petitioned the Administrative Court to suspend the results of the election and accused the Election Commission of violating voter privacy. It accused the commission of placing voting booths so that voters' backs were to the public, when in all previous elections, voters faced the public, with a barrier one-half meter tall at the front of the booth separating the voter from the public. The commission claimed the new arrangement was designed to prevent various forms of polling fraud including the use of cameras by voters to take photographs of their ballots. After the [[Thai general election, 2005|2005 election]], cameras and [[camera phone]]s were banned from voting stations due to fears that canvassers would demand ballot photographs in return for money.[http://www.textually.org/picturephoning/archives/2005/02/006999.htm picturephoning.com: Thai voters banned from using mobile phone cameras at polling booths] {{webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20081122102933/http://www.textually.org/picturephoning/archives/2005/02/006999.htm |date=22 November 2008 }}{{cite web|last1=Rojas|first1=Peter|title=Thailand bans cameraphone pics in voting booths|url=https://www.engadget.com/2005/02/07/thailand-bans-cameraphone-pics-in-voting-booths/|website=Engadget|accessdate=10 February 2017}} However, the PAD claimed that this allowed onlookers to peek over voters' shoulders and see who they voted for.{{cite news|url=http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/04/03/headlines/headlines_30000863.php |title=Administrative Court urged to suspend poll results |work=The Nation |date=7 February 2005 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080821183221/http://nationmultimedia.com/2006/04/03/headlines/headlines_30000863.php |archivedate=21 August 2008 |df=dmy-all }}http://bangkokpost.net/News/03Apr2006_news02.php{{DL|date=February 2017}} The elections were eventually declared invalid by Thailand's [[Constitutional Court of Thailand|Constitutional Court]], which found the positioning of voting booths violated voter privacy. The Constitutional Court forced the Election Commission to resign over its management of the April elections. The court failed to persuade the EC president to resign. It did, however, prevent the Senate from appointing a replacement for commissioner [[Jaral Buranapansri]], who had died.{{CN|date=February 2017}} This prevented the commission from achieving a quorum.{{CN|date=February 2017}} It later found the remaining commissioners guilty of malfeasance and jailed them for one night. An entirely new commission was appointed. ===2007 House election=== {{main|Thai general election, 2007}} [[Image:Thai general election 2007 18.jpg|thumb|350px|right|Polling Station during the [[Thai general election, 2007|2007 election]]]] A number of [[members of parliament|MP]]s (mainly those elected for the PPP) were given "[[Penalty card#Red card|red card]]s" for alleged vote buying, meaning they would not be able to contest the resulting by-elections. Other MPs were issued "[[Penalty card#Yellow card|yellow card]]s" and not banned from contesting the by-elections.{{cite news|title=3 elected candidates of winning party 'yellow-carded'|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6327256.html|date=26 December 2007|work=People's Daily Online}} By 3 January 2008, the Election Commission had endorsed 397 MPs and was still investigating 83 MPs for fraud.{{cite news |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6332029.html |title=Thai election agency endorses 397 candidates winning general election |work=People's Daily Online |date=3 January 2008}} By-elections were held on 13 January, 17 January, 20 January (the day before the first session of the newly elected parliament) and 27 January 2008.{{cite news|url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/6347241.html |title=Thai election agency completes filling House seats |work=People's Daily Online |date=29 January 2008}} The Electoral Commission was still looking into allegations of fraud by PPP deputy leader Yongyuth Tiyaphairat. If given a red card, the PPP faced dissolution. PPP officials stated that they are not worried about dissolution, and that they would simply find a new party instead; local reports stated that a likely candidate for takeover by PPP members would be the [[Thai Land Power Party]] (''Palang Pandin Thai Party'').{{cite news|url=http://news.xinhuanet.com/english/2008-01/13/content_7413332.htm |title=Thailand starts by-elections in Northeast |work=Xinhua |date=13 January 2008}} Disqualified were: *PPP ** red cards for Prakit Poldej, Pornchai Srisuthiyothin, Rungroj Thongsri – [[Buri Ram Province]] constituency 1[http://www.bangkokpost.com/topstories/topstories.php?id=124778 Bangkok Post: Top Stories]{{DL|date=February 2017}} ** yellow cards for Boonlert Krudkhunthod, Linda Cherdchai, Prasert Chanruangthong – [[Nakhon Ratchasima Province]] Constituency 3{{cite news|url=http://enews.mcot.net/view.php?id=2145 |work=MCOT English News |title=Nakhon Ratchasima Constituency 3 set to hold by-election 13 Jan |date=5 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090626215621/http://enews.mcot.net/view.php?id=2145 |archivedate=26 June 2009 |df=dmy-all }} ** yellow card for Thanatorn Losunthorn – [[Lampang Province]] Constituency 1{{cite news|url=http://mathaba.net/news/?x=576888 |title=Poll agency issues yellow card to fourth PPP elected candidate |date=5 January 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150512224905/http://mathaba.net/news/?x=576888 |archivedate=12 May 2015 |df=dmy-all }} ** yellow cards for Surathin Phimarnmekhin, Anan Sriphan, Cherdchai Wichianwan – [[Udon Thani Province]]{{cite news |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6333797.html |title=Thai election agency issues more yellow cards to winning candidates |work=People's Daily Online |date=7 January 2008}} ** yellow cards for Prasop Busarakham and one other MP, with Busarakham's card changed to red later{{cite news |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6336121.html |title=Thai election agency disqualifies poll winner candidate |work=People's Daily Online |date=10 January 2008}} – [[Udon Thani Province]] Constituency 3{{cite news |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6333842.html |title=Thai election agency disqualifies more winning candidates |work=People's Daily Online |date=7 January 2008}} * Thai Nation Party ** red cards for two MPs – [[Chai Nat Province]] * Democrat Party ** yellow card for Suthat Jansaengsi – [[Phetchabun Province]] 86 * For the Motherland Party ** yellow cards for two MPs{{cite news |url=http://english.people.com.cn/90001/90777/90851/6341448.html |title=Thailand starts third round by-elections |work=People's Daily Online |date=20 January 2008}} ===2008 Senate election=== No major event occurred. ===2011 General election=== {{main|Thai general election, 2011}} On 19 July, both [[Yingluck Shinawatra]] and [[Abhisit Vejjajiva]] were acknowledged as members of the [[House of Representatives of Thailand|House]]. On 27 July, the acknowledgement extended to further ninety four elected candidates. Now and eventually, the number acknowledged sufficed to constitute the House. This, however, did not include [[Jatuporn Prompan]] whom the Election Commission declared to have lost the [[suffrage]] due to failure to vote in both the previous and the present elections. The [[2007 Constitution of Thailand|Constitution]] requires that a member of the House must possess the suffrage, and also prescribes that a person failing to vote in an election loses the suffrage but regains it once voting in the next election.{{cite web|url=http://www.thairath.co.th/today/view/189693 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110730210016/http://www.thairath.co.th/today/view/189693 |dead-url=yes |archive-date=30 July 2011 |title=Jatuporn excluded due to failure to vote; further 94 candidates becoming new MPs |date=28 July 2011 |work=Thairath |accessdate=28 July 2011 }} The Election Commission's announcements of the acknowledgement were published in the Government Gazette as follows: {| class="wikitable" |- bgcolor="#ebf5ff" !align="center"|# !align="center"|Announcements !align="center"|Number of candidates acknowledged !align="center"|Date of acknowledgement !align="center"|Published in |- ! colspan="5" bgcolor="#ebf5ff" | Proportional |- | align = "left"|1 | align = "center"| Announcement of the Election Commission,
Re: Results of election of party-proportional members of the House of Representatives,

{{Infobox organization | name = Environmental Integrity Project | image = | image_size = | abbreviation = EIP | motto = | formation = 2002 | founders = Eric Schaeffer, Michele Merkel | type = 501(c)(3) non-profit | purpose = Environmental Advocacy | headquarters = Washington, D.C. | location = | region = | services = | fields = | leader_title = | leader_name = | leader_title2 = | leader_name2 = | leader_title3 = | leader_name3 = | leader_title4 = | leader_name4 = | board_of_directors = | budget = | endowment = | slogan = | mission = | website = http://environmentalintegrity.org/ }}
The '''Environmental Integrity Project (EIP)''' is a Washington, D.C.-based environmental nonprofit organization that advocates for more effective enforcement of environmental laws.<ref name="auto">{{Cite web|title = Environmental Integrity Project|url = http://www.environmentalintegrity.org|website = www.environmentalintegrity.org|accessdate = 2015-08-10}}</ref> The organization was founded in 2002 by former U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) attorneys, Eric V. Schaeffer<ref>{{cite web|url=http://grist.org/article/top-epa-offical-resigns/|title=Read the resignation letter from Eric Schaeffer, former head of the U.S. EPA’s Office of Regulatory|work=Grist}}</ref> and Michele Merkel.<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://environmentalintegrity.org/pdf/abouteip/abouteip_5YearReport.pdf|title = EIP 5-year Report|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref> EIP is known for its [[environmental law|legal]] and investigative efforts to reduce air and water pollution from [[Fossil-fuel power station|coal-fired power plants]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Did Texas Illegally Relax Rules on Coal Plants?|url = http://insideclimatenews.org/news/27052015/did-texas-illegally-relax-rules-coal-plants|accessdate = 2015-08-10}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Tracking groundwater contamination at coal combustion waste disposal sites.|url = http://www.ashtracker.org/|accessdate = 2015-08-10}}</ref> oil and gas facilities,<ref>{{Cite web|url = http://foreffectivegov.org/files/info/2012.10.24_tri_petition_final.pdf|title = TRI Petition|date = |accessdate = |website = |publisher = |last = |first = }}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|title = Plant flares emit more pollutants than previously thought, the EPA reports|url = http://powersource.post-gazette.com/news/environment/2015/04/27/Flares-emit-more-pollutants-than-previously-thought-EPA-updates-find/stories/201504220097|accessdate = 2015-08-10}}</ref> [[Concentrated Animal Feeding Operation|factory farms]],<ref>{{Cite web|title = Green groups sue to end pollution-reporting exemptions for animal feeding operations {{!}} AgriPulse|url = http://www.agri-pulse.com/Green-groups-sue-to-end-pollution-reporting-exemptions-for-animal-feeding-operations-04152015.asp|website = www.agri-pulse.com|accessdate = 2015-08-10}}</ref> and other sources including [[Incineration|incinerators]]<ref>{{Cite web|title = Trash-burning power project hits new snag|url = http://www.baltimoresun.com/features/green/blog/bs-md-incinerator-20150216-story.html|accessdate = 2015-08-10|first = Baltimore|last = Sun}}</ref> and [[Sewage treatment|waste water treatment plants]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = Environmental Groups Sue WSSC Over Plant|url = http://www.nbcwashington.com/news/local/Environmental-Groups-Sue-WSSC-Over-Plant-245266671.html|accessdate = 2015-08-10}}</ref> The group also focuses on [[environmental justice]] and pollution in the [[Chesapeake Bay]]. EIP is headquartered in [[Washington, D.C.|Washington, DC]], and it has another office in [[Austin, Texas|Austin, TX]] and staff in Pennsylvania, Vermont, and Georgia. In 2013, [[Charity Navigator]], an independent charity evaluator, rated EIP as a four-star charity organization.<ref>{{Cite web|title = Charity Navigator Rating - Environmental Integrity Project|url = http://www.charitynavigator.org/index.cfm?bay=search.summary&orgid=14003#.Vciu6flVhuM|website = Charity Navigator|accessdate = 2015-08-10}}</ref>
EIP maintains Ashtracker.org, a website that provides records about groundwater contamination at coal ash dumps. The site relies on industry-reported data from state and company records.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ashtracker.org/docs/about|title=Tracking groundwater contamination at coal combustion waste disposal sites.|last=|first=|date=|website=Ashtracker|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|accessdate=2017-10-12}}</ref>
==Mission==
The Environmental Integrity Project’s objectives are to “1) To provide objective analysis of how the failure to enforce or implement environmental laws increases pollution and affects the public's health; 2) To hold federal and state agencies, as well as individual corporations, accountable for failing to enforce or comply with environmental laws; 3) To help local communities in key states obtain the protection of environmental laws.”<ref name="auto"/>
== See also == * [[List of environmental and conservation organizations in the United States]] * [[Environmental law]]

'''Executive Order 12036''' is a [[United States President]]ial [[Executive Order (United States)|Executive Order]] signed on January 24, 1978, by President [[Jimmy Carter]] that imposed restrictions on and reformed the [[United States Intelligence Community|U.S. Intelligence Community]] along with further banning indirect U.S. involvement in [[assassination]]s. The EO was designed to strengthen and expand [[Executive Order 11905]], which was originally signed by [[Gerald R. Ford]] in 1976.<ref name="eorea">{{cite web|title=United States Foreign Intelligence Activities - Executive Order 12036|url=http://www.fas.org/irp/offdocs/eo/eo-12036.htm|date=January 24, 1978|accessdate=November 27, 2016|website=''Federation of American Scientists''}}</ref><ref name="capeo">{{cite book|last1=Andrew|first1=Christopher|title=For the President's Eyes Only: Secret Intelligence and the American Presidency from Washington to Bush|date=Feb 1995|publisher=HarperCollins|isbn=978-0060170370|page=434|edition=1|url=https://www.amazon.com/Presidents-Eyes-Only-Intelligence-Presidency/dp/0060170379/}}</ref>
==Background & history==
Upon taking office in 1977, President [[Presidency of Jimmy Carter|Jimmy Carter's administration]] with input from [[United States Congress|Congress]] immediately began to revise EO 11905 that was signed late in the previous year. Pressure and the need for reform of the U.S. Intelligence Community still existed from the [[Church Committee|Church]] and [[Pike Committee]]s. EO 12036 would be signed barely a year after Carter took office on January 24, 1978.<ref name="eorea"/><ref name="capeo"/> The EO was hailed by Senator [[Walter D. Huddleston]] and [[Jimmy Carter]] as having the most input from the President and Congress amongst EOs up until that day. Carter also intended the EO to be temporary until new intelligence reform legislation could be put into law.<ref name="capeo"/> EO 12036 would be superseded by new legislation in the future.
==Intelligence reform==
Executive Order 12036 created new oversight committees and offered many new restrictions on the U.S. Intelligence Community. The EO set-up the duties and requirements of two [[United States National Security Council|National Security Council]] [[United States Cabinet|cabinet]]-level committees that had been previously created by Carter in 1977. The Policy Review Committee was given the responsibility of defining priorities for intelligence collection and analysis. The Policy Review committee which was chaired by the [[Director of Central Intelligence]] (DCI) and also included the [[U.S. Vice President|Vice President]], [[U.S. National Security Advisor|National Security Advisor]], [[U.S. Secretary of State|Secretary of State]], [[U.S. Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]] and [[Chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff]] would also prioritize intelligence community budget allocations.<ref name="eorea"/><ref name="capeo"/>
The EO replaced Gerald Ford's (EO 11905) [[Oversight of United States covert operations#Operations Advisory Group|Operations Advisory Group]] and replaced it with the [[Oversight of United States covert operations#NSC Special Coordination Committee|Special Coordination Committee]] which was much like the Policy Review Committee. The EO also imposed a lengthy list of restrictions on the U.S. Intelligence Community to ensure "full compliance with the laws of the United States." One of the main restrictions was that no intelligence operation would be undertaken against a U.S. citizen "unless the President has authorized the type of activity involved and the Attorney General has both approved the particular activity and determined that there is probable cause to believe that the United States person is an agent of a foreign power." This included banning any [[Central Intelligence Agency]] electronic surveillance in the U.S. and leaving the [[Federal Bureau of Investigation]] as the only intelligence community member allowed to conduct physical searches within the U.S.<ref name="eorea"/><ref name="capeo"/>
The EO also created the [[National Foreign Intelligence Board]] (NFIB) in order to assist the DCI with "Production, review, and coordination of national foreign intelligence." The NFIB was chaired by the DCI and included representatives from every agency in the intelligence community. The DCI and agency heads were also expected to keep various congressional committees up to date with intelligence community activity.<ref name="eorea"/><ref name="capeo"/>
The EO also expanded the U.S. ban on assassination by closing "loop-holes" and stating "No person employed by or acting on behalf of the United States Government shall engage in, or conspire to engage in, assassination."<ref name="eorea"/><ref name="capeo"/> This ban on assassination would be restated in [[Executive Order 12333]].<ref>CRS Report for Congress Assassination Ban and E.O. 12333: A Brief Summary January 4th, 2002</ref>
==See also== * [[Targeted killing]]

{{about|the quasi-legal concept||Finders Keepers (disambiguation)}} {{Refimprove|date=December 2009}} '''Finders, keepers''' is an English adage with the premise that when something is unowned or abandoned, whoever finds it first can claim it. This idiom relates to an ancient Roman law of similar meaning and has been expressed in various ways over the centuries.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://dictionary.reference.com/browse/finders,+keepers |title=Finders, keepers | Define Finders, keepers at Dictionary.com |publisher=Dictionary.reference.com |date= |accessdate=2013-05-11}}</ref> Of particular difficulty is how best to define when exactly something is unowned or abandoned, which can lead to legal or ethical disputes.
==Application== *One of the most common uses of "Finders, Keepers" involves [[shipwreck]]s. Under international [[maritime law]], for shipwrecks of a certain age, the original owner may have lost all claim to the cargo. Anyone who finds the wreck can then file a salvage claim on it and place a lien on the vessel, and subsequently mount a [[Marine salvage|salvage]] operation. *Philosophies that advocate a right to own land and other natural resources often appeal to the doctrine of finders keepers in the case of claiming ownership of what was previously unowned (see [[Terra nullius]]). *In the United States, the [[Homestead Act]] allowed people to claim land as their own as long as it was originally unowned and the property was then developed by the claimant. * In the field of [[social simulation]], [[Rosaria Conte]] and [[Cristiano Castelfranchi]] have used "finders, keepers" as a case study for simulating the evolution of [[norm (social)|norms]] in simple societies.<ref>[http://jasss.soc.surrey.ac.uk/2/1/2.html Nicole J. Saam and Andreas Harrer: Simulating Norms, Social Inequality, and Functional Change in Artificial Societies]</ref>
==Children's usage== The children's rhyme upon discovering a lost object is "Finders, keepers; Losers, weepers".
==See also== * ''[[Parker v British Airways Board]]'' [1982] * [[Bailment]] * [[Lost, mislaid, and abandoned property]] * [[Adverse possession]] ("possession is nine-tenths of the law") * [[Uti possidetis]] * ''[[Usucapio]]''/[[Usucaption]] * [[Theft by finding]]
==References== {{reflist}}
